Graphical abstract In this study, eight amino acid-based p-toluenesulfonic acid ionic liquids ([AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs) were successfully prepared by the neutralisation reaction of natural amino acids with p-toluenesulfonic acid (p-TSA). The catalytic performance of the newly synthesized [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs was systematically investigated for biodiesel preparation using lauric acid and ethanol as model reactants. Experimental results demonstrated that proline p-toluenesulfonic acid ionic liquid ([ProH][C7H7O3S]) exhibited optimal catalytic performance for esterification of lauric acid and ethanol with a lower H 0 (1.6601). Response surface methodology (RSM) optimized the process conditions to achieve 96.1 % lauric acid conversion under the following conditions: 14.4 wt% catalyst loading, 16.3:1 ethanol/lauric acid molar ratio, 2.46 h reaction time, and 89 °C temperature. According to the 1H NMR method, the yield of biodiesel (ethyl laurate) was determined to be 96.0 %. The kinetic investigation revealed that the reaction followed first-order kinetic, exhibiting relatively low activation energy (7.04 kJ•mol−1) and a frequency factor reaching 0.208 min−1. Calculated thermodynamic parameters showed ΔH = 3.94 kJ•mol−1, ΔS = -0.268kJ•mol−1•K−1, ΔG = 103.9kJ•mol−1. After undergoing ten reaction cycles, the catalyst maintained 93.9 % of its initial catalytic activity, confirming its excellent structural stability. It was noteworthy that [ProH][C7H7O3S] exhibited homogeneous catalytic properties during the reaction, and the system can achieve spontaneous liquid–liquid partitioning after the reaction, which significantly simplifies the product separation process. The catalyst had the advantages of high catalytic efficiency, green renewability and easy operation, which provided a new catalytic system with the potential of industrialisation for biodiesel production. Keywords Ethyl laurate Proline p-toluenesulfonate ionic liquids Esterification reactions Reaction kinetics Thermodynamic analysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The use of fossil energy plays a pivotal role in human energy production activities, which are the primary contributor to the increase in atmospheric concentrations of greenhouse gases, in particular carbon dioxide, and the problem of their limited reserves is considered a major concern for the future [1]. This type of energy is difficult to utilize in a sustainable way in the long term, both due to the significant environmental burden of its production and the potential risks of its supply system, a double pressure that makes the search for new renewable and eco-friendly energy sources particularly urgent [2]. Amid growing global diesel demand and mounting concerns over its environmental and health impacts, biodiesel is gradually expanding its production scale and application in the global energy market due to its substitution advantages [3,4]. Chemically, biodiesel comprises fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs) synthesized through transesterification of lipid feedstocks, including vegetable oils, animal fats, and other triacylglycerol-rich biomass sources [5]. Currently, the mainstream production process of biodiesel is realized through the transesterification (alcoholysis) reaction between triglycerides and low-carbon alcohols under catalytic conditions, and this technology route has the significant advantage of high industrialization maturity [6]. Biodiesel preparation can alternatively utilize fatty acid esterification with short-carbon alcohols as a viable synthesis pathway. It is an important production route for feedstock with high content of free fatty acid (acid oils) due to their lower cost than refined feedstock [7]. For acidified waste oil, experimental evidence indicates that implementing a two-step sequential process − initial free fatty acid esterification followed by transesterification − significantly enhances reactant conversion efficiency within the feedstock system [4,8]. Beyond biodiesel applications, alkyl esters − synthesized via the esterification of both short- and long-chain carboxylic acids − constitute a critical class of industrial chemicals, with applications spanning fragrance production, polymer additives, pharmaceutical excipients, organic solvents, and fine chemical synthesis [7]. Medium chain fatty acids, predominantly lauric acid (C12:0), are primarily derived from coconut and palm kernel oils, which serve as the most abundant natural sources of these lipid components [9]. As a typical saturated medium-chain fatty acid, lauric acid can be esterified with low-carbon alcohols (methanol and ethanol) to produce corresponding ester products in biodiesel preparation. In this study, the catalytic performance of the newly synthesized [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs was systematically investigated for biodiesel preparation using lauric acid and ethanol as model reactants, whose process advantages stem from the fact that ethanol has better renewability and environmentally friendly characteristics than methanol [10,11]. The catalytic systems in the biodiesel preparation process mainly contain three types: homogeneous catalysts, heterogeneous catalysts and enzyme catalyst systems [12]. Homogeneous catalytic systems are mainly comprised of homogeneous basic catalysts and homogeneous acidic catalysts. Homogeneous alkaline catalytic systems (e.g., NaOH, KOH, NaOCH3, KOCH3) have significant limitations in biodiesel synthesis, which are mainly characterized by high separation energy consumption and low catalyst recycling rate. By contrast, homogeneous acidic catalytic systems (including HCl, H2SO4 and organosulfonic acid, etc.) need to be equipped with corrosion-resistant equipments due to their strong corrosive properties, which significantly increases the cost, requires high temperature and long reaction time, and faces the bottleneck of recycling technology as well [13–15]. The heterogeneous catalytic systems mainly cover three categories: heterogeneous alkaline catalytic systems (e.g. CaO, MgO and other metal oxides), heterogeneous acidic catalytic systems (including zeolites, heteropolyacids and metal oxides, etc.), and nano-catalytic materials (e.g. carbon nanotubes, nanoclay and nanofibers, etc.). Compared to homogeneous catalysts, heterogeneous catalysts exhibit superior process advantages, including facile separation from reaction products and remarkable stability during multiple reuse cycles [16]. However, these catalysts also have certain limitations. The storage stability of heterogeneous basic catalysts is compromised primarily due to their hygroscopic nature; heterogeneous acidic catalysts require high-temperature and long-time to attain ideal conversion; and nano-catalytic materials are mainly due to their relatively complicated preparation process [13]. Enzyme-catalyzed systems have shown potential applications in biodiesel synthesis due to their mild reaction conditions and low by-product generation. However, the system is still limited by the key constraints such as short period of catalytic activity maintenance, low reaction kinetics and insufficient economy [17,18]. To address these persistent challenges, renewable catalytic systems with green features must be developed to replace conventional acid-base catalysis and resolve existing technological bottlenecks. To address these persistent technical limitations, researchers are increasingly concentrating on ionic liquids (ILs) as promising alternatives. ILs, formally defined as salt compounds exhibiting melting points below 100°C, consist of structurally tunable organic cations paired with inorganic anions [19,20]. Their unique physicochemical properties − including low volatility, excellent thermal stability, structural designability, and liquid state at room temperature − enable them to serve as dual-function media for sustainable biodiesel production, acting simultaneously as green solvents and efficient catalysts [21,22]. Fernanda et al [23] employed 1-methylimidazole hydrogensulfate ([HMIM]HSO4) ionic liquid as an acidic catalyst, achieving 95 % conversion in oleic acid–methanol esterification. This ionic liquid shows significant potential to replace conventional homogeneous acid catalysts in esterification reaction. Han et al [24] constructed a lauric acid–methanol esterification reaction system and successfully synthesised methyl laurate with 98.58 % conversion by using ionic liquid 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone hydrogen sulfate ([Hnmp]HSO4) as a catalyst. The results verified that the catalytic system had excellent cyclic stability, and the catalytic activity did not obviously decay after five times of reuse. Recent studies reveal environmental challenges with traditional ILs (halogen, imidazolium, and pyridinium types), including high ecotoxicity, poor biodegradability, and bioaccumulation potential, requiring careful risk evaluation [25,26]. Furthermore, cation sources derived from naturally occurring amino acids demonstrate significantly lower costs compared to conventional imidazolium and pyridinium-based cationic ionic liquids [27]. Consequently, it is desirable to develop green and renewable ILs using natural biological materials for biodiesel preparation. New ILs are undergoing continuous research and development, and the third generation of products integrates natural sugars, amino acids, alkaloids, carboxylic acids and other biobased components to build an ionic system with environmentally compatible characteristics. Based on the unique conformational characteristics of amino acids, which have both carboxylic carboxylate and aminonium functional groups in their molecular structure, they exhibit anionic/cationic bifunctionality in the design of ionic liquids [28]. These biologically derived ionic liquids not only possess chiral recognition and proton transfer properties, but also have modulated hydrophobicity and acid-base synergistic effects, which show their unique advantages in the field of catalysts and enzyme catalysis [29]. Li et al. [30] systematically assessed the catalytic performance of aspartate based nitrate ionic liquid ([Asp][NO3]), 97 % conversion was achieved in oleic acid esterification reaction, and 93.84 % conversion was further obtained in biodiesel production from palmitic acid distillate. The results expressed that this catalytic system was both environmental-friendly and renewable, especially suitable for biodiesel preparation from low-quality oils and fats with high free fatty acids content, and its biodegradable property enhances the process sustainability. Zeng et al. [31] exploited a novel catalyst, proline trifluoromethanesulfonate ([ProH][CF3SO3]) ionic liquid, and tested its effectiveness in the preparation of biodiesel using oleic acid with methanol. It was observed that the effective conversion of oleic acid was as high as 98.97 % under optimal reaction parameters. Notably, the catalyst remained stable after 8 consecutive reuse cycles, demonstrating performance advantages comparable to those of traditional process catalysts, while possessing reusability characteristics, providing a more environmentally friendly catalytic solution for biodiesel production. The production of biodiesel (ethyl laurate) can be affected by several parameters (reaction temperature and time, ethanol-lauric acid ratio, and catalyst type and quantity), which raise the need to apply methods that provide the optimization of the synthesis of biodiesel [32]. It is necessary to develop a method aiming to minimize the experimental runs to optimize the process parameters for biodiesel production, in which response surface methodology (RSM) was found to be a modern and high-efficient approach [33]. RSM is generally employed to predict and optimize the responses and input parameters, respectively. The most advantageous feature of RSM is that it provides valid results in limited experimental runs [34]. Compared with RSM-based Full Factorial design (FFD), Box–Behnken design (BBD) and Central Composite design (CCD) are better fitting methods [35]. Several studies have reported that BBD has been effectively used to optimize several parameters for biodiesel production [23,36,37]. To our knowledge, although p-toluenesulfonic acid (p-TSA) has been well-documented as an acidic catalyst for biodiesel synthesis [38,39], no studies on the use of ILs synthesized using amino acids and p-TSA as catalysts for FFA esterification have been reported. This work constitutes the first systematic investigation of [ProH][C7H7O3S] as a catalyst for ethyl laurate production, addressing a previously unexplored pathway in esterification catalysis. So, eight novel amino acid-based ionic liquids were successfully prepared from p-TSA and various amino acids. The molecular structure of the synthesized ionic liquids ([AAH][C7H7O3S]) were comprehensive charactered by FT-IR and NMR spectra, and their acidic strengths were tested. Subsequently, they were applied to catalyze lauric acid and ethanol esterification for biodiesel preparation. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials The L-amino acids (Pro, Asp, Glu, Met, Arg, Gly, His, and Lys) were procured from Beijing Botop Technology Co Ltd. (Beijing, China). Fatty acids (lauric acid (AV = 256.3 mgKOH•g−1), oleic acid (AV = 154.0 mgKOH•g−1) and stearic acid (AV = 185.6 mgKOH•g−1)) and p-toluenesulfonic acid were sourced from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Methanol, ethanol, isopropanol, ether, and potassium hydroxide were obtained from Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent Factory (Tianjin, China). All reagents are of analytical-grade and were not further purified in the experiment. The heat-gathering constant-temperature magnetic stirrer (DF-101S) is from Gongyi Yuhua Instrument Co., LTD. (Gongyi, China). The rotary evaporator (RE-52AA) and the circulating water vacuum pump (SHZ-III) are all from Shanghai Yarong Biochemical Instrument Factory (Shanghai, China). 2.2 Catalyst synthesis The [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs were synthesized via a modified procedure [40,41]. As an example, the synthesis of [ProH][C7H7O3S] was performed through the following procedure: an equalimolar (1:1 M ratio) mixture of proline and p-toluenesulfonic acid were dissolved in deionized water. The reaction mixture was stirred at 25 °C for 24 h using a thermostated magnetic stirrer. The resultant mixture underwent solvent removal via rotary evaporation, followed by vacuum drying at 70°C for 24 h in a vacuum oven. The synthetic pathway is schematically illustrated in Scheme 1 . Other [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs were obtained through the same protocol. 2.3 Characterization of [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs The acid strength distribution of catalysts in ethanol solution was quantitatively determined using UV–vis spectroscopy (Varioskan LUX, USA) with 4-nitroaniline as the indicator. The Hammett function (H 0) of [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs was determined spectrophotometrically by monitoring the protonation-induced absorbance changes of 4-nitroaniline. The protonation equilibrium of 4-nitroaniline (72.4 μmol•L−1 in ethanol) exhibited characteristic absorbance attenuation at 371 nm when titrated with [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs (1 mmol•L−1). The Hammett acidity function (H0 ) was expressed by Equation (1). (1) H 0 = p K a + log([I]/[I H + ]) where pKa (0.99) corresponds to the dissociation constant of 4-nitroaniline, [I] and [IH±] represent the molarities of deprotonated and protonated forms of indicator, respectively. The [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs were characterized by FTIR spectroscopy (Bruker VERTEX 70, Germany) using KBr pellets (4000 to 500 cm−1). 1H and 13C NMR saectra were recorded on a Bruker BioSpin spectrometer (Switzerland) using D2O as solvent. The thermal stability of [ProH][C7H7O3S] was assessed by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA Q500 V2013 Build 39, USA) under nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C•min−1. 2.4 Catalytic testing The [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs was assessed as catalysts for lauric acid esterification with ethanol in a magnetically stirred batch reactor under reflux conditions, the batch reactor setup in this work was shown in Fig. S2. Reaction mixtures containing ionic liquids, lauric acid, and ethanol were heated in thermostated oil baths for predetermined durations. Lauric acid (10 g), various ILs (1 g), and ethanol (molar ratio 9:1) were placed in a 250 mL three-necked flask. Then, the flask containing this mixture was placed in an oil bath and gradually heated to 70 °C. After completing the reaction, the unreacted ethanol was removed via rotary evaporation, followed by phase separation in a graduated separatory funnel. The catalyst was recovered from the lower phase via vacuum distillation to remove residual water, and subsequently recycled for the next reaction cycle. The upper phase (ethyl laurate) was quantified by directly titration with KOH-EtOH standard solution, followed by calculation of the acid value (AV) according to GB 5009.229-2016 (Chinese national standard). The AV (mgKOH•g−1) of sample was calculated using Equation (2) as follows. (2) AV = C( V 1 - V 2 )[MULSGN]56.11 M where 56.11 corresponds to the molar mass of KOH (g•mol−1), C represents the standard solution concentration (mol•L−1), M indicates the sample mass (g), and V1 and V2 represent the volume of KOH-EtOH solution consumed in titrating the sample and the blank (mL), respectively. Lauric acid conversion was determined through Equation (3) [42]. (3) Conversion(\%) = AV 0 - AV AV 0 [MULSGN] 100 % where AV0 represents the initial acid value of lauric acid feedstock, and AV corresponds to the acid value of the esterified product. 2.5 Optimization of experimental conditions The optimization of reaction parameters was achieved through single-factor experiments followed by RSM with Box-Behnken Design (BBD) [43,44]. Firstly, the single-factor method was performed at different catalyst loading (4.0–16.0 wt%), ethanol/lauric acid molar ratio (5.0–21.0:1), reaction time (0.5–4.0 h), and reaction temperature (70.0–100.0°C). Subsequently, RSM-BBD was implemented to optimize the conversion rate while assessing the effects of variable interactions during esterification on lauric acid conversion. The experimental design employed four independent variables, each with three levels (Table 1 ). A total of 29 experiments were conducted, with lauric acid conversion serving as the response variable. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) was used to evaluate the model accuracyand analyze the significance of individual factors on the response variable. The quantitative relationship between response variables and experimental factors was established through the following regression model: (4) Y = Î́ 0 + ∑ i=1 4 δ i X i + ∑ i=1 4 δ ii X i 2 + ∑ i=1 3 ∑ j=i+1 4 δ ij X i X j + Îµ where Y represents the response value, δ0 , δi , δii , and δij denote the regression coefficients (constant, linear effect, squared effect, and interaction effect terms), X i and X j denote the independent variables, and ε denotes the random error, respectively. 2.6 Kinetic modeling and thermodynamics Reaction kinetics were systematically investigated under parameters (14.4 wt% catalyst dosage, 16.3:1 M ratio) across thermal conditions of 60 − 80°C, with kinetic sampling performed at fixed 25 min intervals. The equation for lauric acid esterification catalyzed by [ProH][C7H7O3S] can be simplified as follows: (5) C H 3 C H 2 10 C O O H + C H 3 C H 2 O H ⟷ k 1 k 2 C H 3 C H 2 10 C O O O C H 2 C H 3 + H 2 O Therefore, Equation (6) was used to illustrate the reaction rate [42]. (6) r A = - d C A dt = k 1 C A a C B b - k 2 C C c C D d where, the concentrations of the reactants (lauric acid and ethanol) and the products (ethyl laurate and water) are represented by CA , CB , CC , and CD , respectively; their respective reaction orders are represented by a, b, c, and d, respectively; the rate constants of the positive and reverse reactions are represented by k1 and k2 represents, respectively. Because a large amount of ethanol was used, the reverse reaction is negligible, so CB can be viewed constant throughout the reaction. Therefore, it is anticipated that lauric acid esterification catalyzed by [ProH][C7H7O3S] would adhere to pseudo-first-order kinetics [23]. Thus, the reaction rate equation can be transformed to Equation (7). (7) r A = - d C A dt = k C A a where k = k 1 C B b At the reaction initiation (t = 0), the lauric acid concentration is CA0 . A quantitative relationship exists between the real-time concentration CA in the system and the conversion X, governed by: CA  = CA0 (1-X). Equation (7) will transform to Equation (8). (8) r A = - d C A dt = - d[ C A0 1-X ] dt = C A0 dX dt = k [ C A0 1-X ] a Therefore, Equation (9) can be obtained as follows: (9) dX dt = k [ C A0 1-X ] a C A0 = k 3 [ C A0 (1-X)] a where k3  = k/CA0 . In accordance with the assumptions above, the reaction can be presented by a pseudo-first-order irreversible kinetic model ( a  = 1) [45]. By integrating Equation (9), Equation (10) can be obtained. (10) - ln ( 1-X ) = k 3 t According to Equation (10), a graph was plotted with −ln(1 − X) vs t. The relationship between −ln(1 − X) and t was shown as a straight line, demonstrating that Equation (10) was reasonable for this esterification reaction [42]. So, k can be determined using linear regression analysis [46]. By using the k values obtained from Equation (10) under temperature conditions of 70, 80, and 90°C), Ea and A can be obtained via Equation (11) [30,47]. Thermodynamic parameters, such as ΔH, ΔS, and ΔG, are essential for evaluating esterification reactions [48]. In line with the transition state theory, ΔG is defined as the peak energy in a chemical reaction [49]. The Eyring-Polanyi equation Equation (12) is employed to calculate ΔG [50], as follows: (12) ln k T = - Δ H RT + ln k b h + Δ S R (13) Δ G = Δ H - T Δ S where, kb stands Boltzmann constant (1.38 × 10−23 J•k−1), h stands Planck constant (6.63 × 10−34 J•s). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst selection Under fixed reaction parameters (2 h, 70 °C, 10 wt% catalyst loading, 9:1 alcohol-acid ratio), eight [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs were systematically screened for catalytic performance in the lauric acid esterification with ethanol. The catalytic performance was systematiclly compared with Pro and p-TSA controls, with detailed comparative data presented in Fig. 1 . These results demonstrate substantial divergence in catalytic efficiency during lauric acid esterification processes. Only 5.4 % conversion was obtained under non-catalytic conditions, while the conversion was enhanced to 93.8 % when p-TSA was used as a catalyst. Notably, the catalytic efficiencies were even lower than those of the blank control group when using Pro, [MetH][C7H7O3S], [GlyH][C7H7O3S], [HisH][C7H7O3S], [LysH][C7H7O3S], and [ArgH][C7H7O3S] as catalysts, indicating that these substances do not possess effective catalytic activities. Among the series of [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs, [ProH][C7H7O3S] exhibited the optimal catalytic performance (84.4 % conversion), but it was still 9.5 percentage points lower than that of p-TSA. This difference may stem from the stronger proton activation ability of p-TSA, which promotes the formation of lauric acid intermediates more efficiently [51]. Despite p-TSA demonstrating the highest catalytic activity, its non-recoverable nature and poor phase-separation behavior significantly limit practical applications. Considering the acid-catalyzed nature of the esterification reaction, the Brønsted acidity of [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs was quantitatively assessed via Hammett acidity function (H0 ) measurements using 4-nitroaniline as the indicator, establishing correlations with observed catalytic performance variations. Fig. 2 displays the UV–vis absorbance spectra of 4-nitroaniline in ethanol with three [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs. The Hammett acidity values (H0 ) of various [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs were determined via Equation (1), with results compiled in Table 2 . The measured H0 values ([ProH][C7H7O3S] < [AspH][C7H7O3S] < [GluH][C7H7O3S]) exhibited excellent correlation with the observed catalytic activity trend. The inverse correlation between H0 and acidity was confirmed, with [ProH][C7H7O3S] exhibiting the strongest acidity (H0  = 1.6601). All three [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs demonstrate Brønsted acidity due to amino group in the amino acid protonation during synthesis, consistent with reported behavior of [ProH][CF3SO3] [7]. So, [ProH][C7H7O3S] was chose as the preferred catalyst for lauric acid esterification. 3.2 Characterization of [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs 3.2.1 FTIR Fig. 3 demonstrate the FTIR spectra of eight synthesized [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs. The FTIR spectra demonstrated distinct correlations between characteristic absorption bands of ionic liquids and their constituent amino acid side chain functional groups. FTIR spectra showed the characteristic (S=O) stretching vibration at 1030 cm−1 in all samples, indicating preservation of the sulfonic acid functionality during synthesis [52]. Characteristic amino acid vibrations were identified at 3000 cm−1 (C-H), 1750 cm−1 (C=O), and 1160 cm−1 (C-N). Notably, [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs showed stretching vibrational features of the −N-H2- group in the range of 3200–3500 cm−1 [31,53–56]. The high degree of consistency of the key characteristic peaks among the spectra and the non-detection of feedstock characteristic peaks (e.g., the C=O signal of the free amino acid at 1700 cm−1) confirmed the successful synthesis of the target ionic liquid. 3.2.2 NMR The structural confirmation of [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs was achieved through 1H and 13C NMR analysis, with characteristic chemical shifts detailed in Table S1 (Supplementary Information). Taking [ProH][C7H7O3S] as an example, the signals at 2.82 ppm, 4.69 ppm, and 1.23 ppm in the 1H NMR spectrum correspond to the methyl group (–CH3) of the p-toluenesulfonate anion, the methylene group adjacent to the nitrogen atom (–CH-N) in the prolinium cation, and the methylene group (–CH2-) within the cyclic structure, respectively. In the 13C NMR spectrum, the signals at 21.26 ppm and 54.25 ppm are assigned to the methyl carbon (–CH3) of p-toluenesulfonate and the carbon atom bonded to the nitrogen atom (–CH2-N) in the prolinium ring, respectively. No apparent impurity signals were discovered in the NMR spectra of all [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs, indicating that the synthesized products met the purity requirements for this study. 3.2.3 TGA The evolution of thermal stability of [ProH][C7H7O3S] in the temperature interval of 20–600 °C was systematically investigated using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Fig. 4 ). It is clear that the TG curve that [ProH][C7H7O3S] displayed outstanding thermal stability with an onset decomposition temperature of ∼150 °C, exhibiting merely ∼ 8 % mass loss during the initial heating stage (40−150°C). The observed mass reduction likely originates from the thermal desorption of physisorbed water molecules present on the [ProH][C7H7O3S] ionic liquid surface [57]. The second decomposition stage (150−600°C) exhibited a sharp mass loss of 75 %, corresponding to the complete thermal degradation of the [ProH][C7H7O3S]. The decomposition temperature of ionic liquids exhibits strong dependence on both the structural characteristics of constituent ions and their intermolecular interactions. This thermal robustness ensures the structural integrity of [ProH][C7H7O3S] during subsequent experimental procedures below 150 °C. 3.3 Effect of reaction conditions 3.3.1 Reaction temperature The effect of reaction temperature on the lauric acid conversion was investigated under fixed conditions: 10 % catalyst loading, and 1:9 M ratio. The experimental data presented in Fig. 5a demonstrated that the lauric acid conversion increased from 87.4 % to 93.7 % with temperature rising from 70 to 80 °C in 2.5 h. The observed phenomenon results from the endothermic characteristic of esterification, as higher temperatures thermodynamically promote the forward reaction [30,43]. However, at elevated temperatures (>80 °C, ranging from 80 to 100 °C), the lauric acid conversion exhibits temperature independence. This plateau behavior likely results from the reversible nature of esterification, where the system reaches thermodynamic equilibrium at approximately 80°C. Consequently, 80 °C was identified as the most favorable reaction temperature. 3.3.2 Ethanol/lauric acid molar ratio At constant conditions (10% catalyst, 80 °C), esterification efficiency was evaluated across ethanol/lauric acid molar ratios of 5:1 to 21:1 (Fig. 5b), revealing significant stoichiometric effects. As detailed in Fig. 5b, lauric acid conversion showed stoichiometry-dependent enhancement, reaching 95.2 % at 13:1 ethanol ratio compared to 90.3 % at 5:1 ratio after 2.5 h of reaction. No significant conversion enhancement was observed when the molar ratio was elevated beyond 13:1 (tested up to 21:1). While moderate ethanol amounts promote reactant molecular interactions and rate enhancement, supra-stoichiometric quantities cause catalyst dilution that ultimately retards the esterification reaction [58]. A molar ratio of 17:1 (ethanol/lauric acid) was found to be optimal based on the reaction results. 3.3.3 Catalyst loading A systematic investigation of catalyst loading effects (4–16 wt%) on lauric acid conversion was conducted at fixed reaction conditions: ethanol-to-lauric acid molar ratio of 13:1 and temperature of 80 °C (Fig. 5c). As illustrated in Fig. 5c, the 2.5 h reaction profile showed a clear trend of increasing conversion rate corresponding to higher catalyst loadings across the tested range. Specifically, the lauric acid conversion increased from 84.1 % to 96.0 % as catalyst loading rose from 4 to 14 wt%. Nevertheless, when the catalyst loading exceeded 14 wt% (ranging from 14 to 16 wt%), no substantial increase in conversion was observed. Since catalysts facilitate both forward and reverse reactions, an excessive amount can drive unfavorable side reactions, ultimately decreasing conversion [59]. In light of these results, 14 wt% was selected as the ideal catalyst loading. 3.3.4 Reaction time The effect of reaction time on lauric acid conversion was systematically investigated through a segmented experimental approach (Fig. 5a–c). The conversion exhibited a time-dependent increase, rising from initial values at 0.5 h to reach maximum conversion efficiency at the 2.5 h. The lauric acid conversion plateaued after 2.5 h, suggesting the lauric acid esterification had reached equilibrium by this time [30,60]. At 2.5 h, the reaction time is significantly shorter than both [Asp][NO3] (3.5 h) [30] and [Gly-TPA] (3.0 h) [60]. Among tested durations, 2.5 h demonstrated superior catalytic efficiency for lauric acid esterification when using [ProH][C7H7O3S] as a catalyst. 3.4 RSM analysis 3.4.1 Model fitting and ANOVA Table 3 presented the 29 experiment designs based on BBD. It was obvious that the predicted and experimental conversion values have a small error range, which meant the model was reliable [43,44]. The quadratic polynomial model describing lauric acid conversion was derived from Table 3 data and is presented in Equation (14): (14) Y = + 95.28 + 1.59 X 1 + 1.28 X 2 + 0.2667 X 3 + 0.3583 X 4 - 0.4000 X 1 X 2 + 0.1500 X 1 X 3 - 0.2250 X 1 X 4 + 0.0750 X 2 X 3 - 0.1250 X 2 X 4 - 0.3250 X 3 X 4 - 0.9025 X 1 2 - 0.6150 X 2 2 + 0.0350 X 3 2 - 0.4275 X 4 2 where X1 , X2 , X3 and X4 represent reaction temperature, ethanol to lauric acid molar ratio, catalyst loading, and the reaction time, respectively; Y represents the response value (lauric acid conversion). The results of ANOVA and regression analysis for the 29 experimental runs were summarized in Table 4 , confirming the model’s statistical significance and good fit through standard variance analysis. The regression model demonstrated high statistical significance with an F-value of 71.74 (p < 0.0001). The non-significant lack-of-fit test (p > 0.05) further confirms the model’s adequacy at the 95 % confidence level [61]. The model exhibited good reliability as evidenced by the minimal difference (0.029) between its calibration (R2 = 0.973) and prediction (R2 = 0.944) performance, well below the 0.2 acceptability threshold. The model exhibited excellent explanatory power with R2 = 0.986, accounting for 98.6 % of response variability. The high Adeq Precision value (33.34, significantly above the threshold of 4) further confirmed strong predictive capability and robust signal-to-noise characteristics [62]. The comprehensive statistical analysis confirmed the validity and reliability of the regression model, demonstrating its predictive capability for assessing the effect of various factors on lauric acid conversion [43]. 3.4.2 Effect of process variables 3D Contour plots derived from Equation (14) revealed both the optimal operating conditions and the underlying interaction effects between key parameters. Fig. 6 graphically illustrated how these variables interact synergistically to influence lauric acid conversion. The synergistic interactions among temperature, substrate ratio, catalyst loading, and reaction duration are distinctly illustrated in Fig. 6a–c, respectively. As the temperature rises, lauric acid conversion rate increases fastly, peaks at 89 °C, and subsequently decrease. Lauric acid conversion consistently improves with increasing substrate molar ratios. Unlike the substrate ratio effect, higher catalyst loading or longer reaction times did not increase conversion rate. This suggests that substrate ratio affects conversion more than temperature, which in turn has a stronger effect than catalyst loading and reaction time. Fig. 6d–e illustrates the correlation between substrate ratio, catalyst loading, and reaction time. The data indicate that lauric acid conversion stabilizes when the substrate ratio exceeds 16.5. In contrast, neither increasing catalyst loading nor extending reaction time improved conversion. These results demonstrate that substrate ratio more effectively promotes lauric acid conversion than catalyst loading or reaction time. Fig. 6f demonstrates that both catalyst loading and reaction time positively correlate with lauric acid conversion, revealing their synergistic effect. Notably, reaction time exhibits a stronger influence on conversion efficiency than catalyst loading. The comprehensive analysis reveals parameter effects on conversion in descending order: ethanol-lauric acid molar ratio > reaction temperature > reaction time > catalyst loading, aligning with the findings presented in Table 4. Following RSM optimization (X1 = 89°C, X2 = 16.3:1, X3 = 14.4 wt%, X4 = 2.46 h), the predicted conversion efficiency (96.4 %) closely matched experimental results (96.1 % ± 0.11 %, n = 3), corresponding to a mere 0.3 % relative error. The excellent agreement between experimental and predicted values (relative error < 0.5 %) robustly validates the model’s high predictive accuracy and reliability. 3.5 Reaction mechanism Following the established mechanism of acid-catalyzed esterification [51,63–66], we propose a five-step reaction pathway (Scheme 2 ) for the [ProH][C7H7O3S]-catalyzed lauric acid esterification with ethanol. Firstly, The –NH3 + group of the [Pro]+ side chain facilitates proton transfer from the catalyst’s acidic site to the carbonyl oxygen of lauric acid, generating a protonated intermediate. This activation significantly increases the electrophilicity of the carbonyl carbon. Secondly, deprotonated ethanol nucleophiles attack the electrophilic carbonyl carbon, forming a tetrahedral intermediate. Thirdly, proton transfer to the intermediate induces decomposition, yielding water as a byproduct. Fourthly, water molecules generated through intermediate decomposition are liberated. Finally, the catalytic cycle concludes with spontaneous desorption of biodiesel products from the [ProH][C7H7O3S] active sites, accompanied by full regeneration of the catalytic centers for subsequent turnover cycles. 3.6 Characterization of ethyl laurate products The formed product (ethyl laurate) and lauric acid (raw material) were confirmed by FT-IR analysis, with their characteristic spectra displayed in Fig. 7 . The absorption peak observed at 2925 cm−1 is attributed to the C-H stretching vibration in the long-chain alkyl groups of both lauric acid and ethyl laurate. A broad absorption band appearing at 2690 cm−1 arises from the O-H stretching vibration of the carboxylic acid group in lauric acid. Additionally, the characteristic peak at 1305 cm−1 results from the C-O bond stretching vibration within the carboxylic acid structure of lauric acid. Comparative FT-IR analysis revealed the complete disappearance of the broad hydroxyl stretching vibration (2500–3300 cm−1) characteristic of lauric acid, accompanied by the emergence of a new intense ester carbonyl absorption at 1700 cm−1. These spectral changes are consistent with the characteristic pattern of ester bond formation. The detection of the 1180 cm−1 absorption band (attributed to ester C-O-C asymmetric stretching) further confirmed the presence of the newly formed ester functionality. The systematic evolution of characteristic spectral features, corroborated by experimental measurements, unequivocally confirmed the successful synthesis of the target compound (ethyl laurate). 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectral of the synthesized biodiesel (ethyl laurate) was recorded on a Bruker Avance III HD spectrometer (600 MHz; Bruker BioSpin, Switzerland). CDCl3 was chosen as the solvent. The spectra were shown in Fig. S2 (Supplementary Information). According to the previous reported method [76], 96.0 % biodiesel (ethyl laurate) yield can be obtained from the result of 1H NMR analysis. The signal appears at 4.12 ppm in 1H NMR spectra confirms the ethyl laurate formation, which is −O-CH2- peak after esterification. 3.7 Comparison with other IL catalysts For lauric acid esterification with ethanol catalyzed by IL [ProH][C7H7O3S], the turn over frequency (TOF) − a crucial indicator of catalytic performance [1,67,68] − was calculated to be 0.0139 mol•g−1•h−1 using Equation (15). The catalytic performance comparison of varied IL catalysts for FFAs esterification under optimized reaction conditions is shown in Table 5 . The obtained TOF value significantly surpasses those reported for typocal IL catalysts, including [BHSO3MIM]HSO4, [HMIM]HSO4, [Asp][NO3], [GluH][CH3SO3], and [ProH][CF3SO3]. Furthermore, the conversion rate achieved in the lauric acid–ethanol esterification catalyzed by [ProH][C7H7O3S] is comparable to that reported for various fatty acid–methanol systems using other ionic liquid catalysts. The reaction time for lauric acid–ethanol esterification was observed to be moderately longer than recorded for the [C3SO3Hnhp]HSO4 and [ProH][CF3SO3]-catalyzed esterification of lauric acid/oleic acid with methanol. However, it remains significantly shorter than the reaction times observed for fatty acid esterification catalyzed by other ionic liquids (including [BHSO3-MIM]HSO4, [HIM]HSO4, [Asp][NO3], and [GluH][CH3SO3]). (15) TOF = \% Conversion lauric aicd (Time)(Catalyst wt.\%)(Molar mass lauric acid) To evaluate the substrate versatility of the IL catalyst, [ProH][C7H7O3S]-mediated esterification was systematically investigated using various FFAs (oleic acid, lauric acid, stearic acid) and alcohols (methanol, ethanol). As shown in Fig. 8 , the catalyst demonstrated remarkable efficiency across all tested combinations, achieving conversion of 93.2 % for methyl laurate, 97 % for methyl oleate, 98.2 % for methyl stearate, 94.7 % for ethyl oleate, and 96.3 % for ethyl stearate under optimized conditions (2.46 h, 14.4 wt% catalyst loading, 89°C, 16.3:1 substrate ratio). These results conclusively demonstrated the catalytic versatility of [ProH][C7H7O3S] in biodiesel synthesis across various feedstock sources. 3.8 Kinetic and thermodynamic studies The kinetic behavior of lauic acid esterification was examined at different temperatures (80, 90, and 100 °C), with other parameters fixed at their optimal values (molar ratio 16.3:1, catalyst loading 14.4 wt%, time 2.46 h). Kinetics analysis revealed pseudo-first-order kinetic behavior (Equation (10)), demonstrated by excellent linear correlations (R2 > 0.98) of −ln(1-X) versus t plots across the tested temperatures (80, 90 and 100 °C) (Fig. 9 ), in agreement with with literature fingings. So, the rate constants (k) corresponding to different temperatures were determined from the slopes obtained through linear regressions of the data in Fig. 9, with the calculated values presented in Table 6 . The rate constants exhibited a clear temperature dependence, increasing from 0.0189 L•mol−1•min−1 at 80°C to 0.0215 L•mol−1•min−1 at 100°C, with intermediate values of 0.0204 (90°C). The experimental results demonstrated a positive correlation between the rate constant (k) and temperature, aligning with the endothermic nature of esterification reactions [71,72]. This temperature dependence indicates that elevated temperatures thermodynamically favor the forward reaction. Linear regression analysis of ln k vs 1/T was performed using the data from Table 6, with the results presented in Fig. 10 . The high coefficient of determination (R2 = 0.9988) obtained from the linear regression in Fig. 10 indicates a strong correlation, validating the use of the slope and intercept to calculate the reaction kinetic parameters [73]. The activation energy (Ea) and frequency factor (A) were determined from the slope and intercept of the linear regression equation. Quantitative analysis revealed that the ethyl laurate synthesis reaction catalyzed by [ProH][C7H7O3S] exhibits an activation energy of 7.04 kJ•mol−1 with a corresponding frequency factor of 0.208 min−1. The observed kinetic behavior shows excellent agreement with the pseudo-first-order reaction model, thereby demonstrating that lauric acid esterification in this catalytic system follows pseudo-first-order reaction kinetics. Table 7 presents a comparative analysis of kinetic parameters for the [ProH][C7H7O3S]-catalyzed lauric acid esterification with reported catalytic systems. The results reveal that [ProH][C7H7O3S] exhibits significantly lower activation energy (Ea) compared to [Hnmp]HSO4 [31,74], [Asp][NO3] [30], [ProH][CF3SO3] [31], and [GluH][CH3SO3] [70], though marginally higher than that of the [HMIM]HSO4 [23]. Collectively, the lower activation energy (Ea) observed for [ProH][C7H7O3S] suggests that this catalytic system can effectively lower the reaction energy barrier, thereby facilitating the reaction progression under relatively mild temperature conditions. According to Equation (12), thermodynamic parameters ΔH and ΔS were determined through van't Hoff analysis, where ΔH was derived from the slope and ΔS from the intercept of the linear plot of ln(k/T) versus 1/T (Fig. 11 ). The value of ΔG under different temperature conditions were calculated using Equation (13), with all derived parameters systematically presented in Table 8 . Table 8 revealed that the [AAH][C7H7O3S]-catalyzed esterification exhibited a positive enthalpy change (ΔH > 0), confirming the endothermic nature of the reaction process [50]. Furthermore, the positive Gibbs free energy values (ΔG > 0) observed at all three investigated temperatures demonstrate the non-spontaneous character of this reaction, necessitating continuous thermal energy input to drive the reaction forward [75]. Moreover, the negative entropy change (ΔS < 0) indicates a decrease in molecular ordering within the reaction system, suggesting the formation of more organized transition states during the catalytic process [50,75]. Consistent with literature data in Table 9 , the reaction thermodynamics follow the established pattern for acid-catalyzed esterification: positive enthalpy changes indicating heat absorption, positive free energy values demonstrating non-spontaneity, and consequent need for sustained heating. 3.9 Stability and reusability Highly stable and reusable catalysts offer A with High stable and reusable catalysts offer a promising strategy for substantially lowering production costs. So, we investigated the possibility of recycling of [ProH][C7H7O3S]. The lower phase obtained after esterification completion was found to contain the [ProH][C7H7O3S], unreacted ethanol, and some reaction-generated water. Ethanol and water were eliminated from the mixture by rotary evaporation. Next, the [ProH][C7H7O3S] was vacuum-dried at 70 °C for 5 h. Finally, the recycling of [ProH][C7H7O3S] was systematically investigated under optimized conditions (89 °C, 16.3:1, 14.4 wt%, 2.46 h). As shown in Fig. 12 , the [ProH][C7H7O3S] catalyst maintained substantial catalytic activity through 10 consecutive reuse cycles, and the lauric acid conversion still reached 93.9 %. In addition, FT-IR spectra of the catalyst before and after ten usage cycles were systematically compared (Fig. S3 (Supplementary Information)). Comparative FT-IR analysis demonstrates excellent spectral matching between the recovered and fresh catalyst, suggesting that the acidic functional groups in [ProH][C7H7O3S] maintain structural integrity after esterification without observable separation. This demonstrates the catalyst’s excellent activity and stability. 3.10 Cost analysis for catalyst preparation Based on the catalyst cost estimation method reported in the literature [79], the preparation cost of the present catalyst was preliminarily estimated. The production cost analysis for the proline p-toluenesulfonic acid ionic liquid ([ProH][C7H7O3S]) catalyst synthesis (per kilogram basis) is presented in Table S2 (Supplementary Information), with all values standardized to US dollars ($). Based on the wholesale quotations from Alibaba 1688 B2B marketplace (https://www.1688.com), the prices of L-proline and p-TSA acid are $1.40 and $5.00 per kilogram, respectively. The while manufacturing 1 kg of [ProH][C7H7O3S] catalyst without reuse is $7.26. The cost of [ProH][C7H7O3S] catalyst is low compared to sulphonic-acid functionalized Limonia acidissima carbonaceous catalyst (“acid doped catalyst” (ADC)) ($49.498 per kilogram) [79]. The synthesis of 1 kg of ethyl laurate requires 126 g of [ProH][C7H7O3S], corresponding to a catalyst cost of approximately $0.091. Since [ProH][C7H7O3S] can be reused at least 10 times, the actual production cost can be further reduced to $0.726. The step-wise biodiesel (ethyl laurate) preparation cost has been summarized in Table S3 (Supplementary Information). The production cost of 1 kg of ethyl laurate catalyzed by [ProH][C7H7O3S] catalyst is $2.229, and the cost of 1 kg of biodiesel catalyzed by ADC from Karanja oil is $0.266 [79]. Due to the use of commercialized lauric acid as a raw material for ethyl laurate synthesis, the cost of producing 1 kg of ethyl laurate is higher than that of ADC catalyst catalyzed Karanja oil. However, ionic liquid ([ProH][C7H7O3S]) can be used to catalyze the esterification of low-cost raw materials (e.g., waste cooking oil) to produce biodiesel, which will reduce the cost of biodiesel. 4 Conclusions Through neutralization reactions between amino acids and p-toluenesulfonic acid, eight amino acid-based ionic liquids were successfully synthesized. Structural characterization by FT-IR and 1H/13C NMR confirmed the expected [AAH][C7H7O3S] configurations. Thermal stability evaluation via TGA demonstrated that [ProH][C7H7O3S] exhibits remarkable thermal resistance up to 150°C. Hammett acidity tests revealed the strong Brønsted acidity of [ProH][C7H7O3S], correlating with its superior catalytic activity in biodiesel preparation. Through systematic optimization combining single-factor experiments with BBD, the reaction parameters were optimized as follows: catalyst loading 14.4 wt%, ethanol-to-lauric acid molar ratio 16.3:1, temperature 89°C, and time 2.46 h. Under these conditions, lauric acid conversion reached 96.1 %. Kinetic studies showed that the reaction conformed to a first-order kinetic model with an activation energy (Ea) of 7.04 kJ•mol−1 and a frequency factor of 0.208 min−1. The thermodynamic parameters ΔH, ΔS and ΔG of lauric acid esterification were 3.94 kJ•mol−1, −0.268 kJ•mol−1•K−1 and 103.9 kJ•mol−1, respectively. Catalytic performance evaluation showed that [ProH][C7H7O3S] maintained consistent activity through 10 consecutive reaction cycles, with lauric acid conversion remaining at 93.9 %, demonstrating remarkable operational stability. The catalyst has the advantages of simple synthesis process, convenient operation and reusability, making it a viable replacement for conventional acid catalysts in biodiesel preparation through fatty acid esterification. coredata.dc:description: In this study, eight amino acid-based p-toluenesulfonic acid ionic liquids ([AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs) were successfully prepared by the neutralisation reaction of natural amino acids with p-toluenesulfonic acid (p-TSA). The catalytic performance of the newly synthesized [AAH][C7H7O3S]-ILs was systematically investigated for biodiesel preparation using lauric acid and ethanol as model reactants. Experimental results demonstrated that proline p-toluenesulfonic acid ionic liquid ([ProH][C7H7O3S]) exhibited optimal catalytic performance for esterification of lauric acid and ethanol with a lower H 0 (1.6601). Response surface methodology (RSM) optimized the process conditions to achieve 96.1 % lauric acid conversion under the following conditions: 14.4 wt% catalyst loading, 16.3:1 ethanol/lauric acid molar ratio, 2.46 h reaction time, and 89 °C temperature. According to the 1H NMR method, the yield of biodiesel (ethyl laurate) was determined to be 96.0 %. The kinetic investigation revealed that the reaction followed first-order kinetic, exhibiting relatively low activation energy (7.04 kJ•mol−1) and a frequency factor reaching 0.208 min−1. Calculated thermodynamic parameters showed ΔH = 3.94 kJ•mol−1, ΔS = -0.268kJ•mol−1•K−1, ΔG = 103.9kJ•mol−1. After undergoing ten reaction cycles, the catalyst maintained 93.9 % of its initial catalytic activity, confirming its excellent structural stability. It was noteworthy that [ProH][C7H7O3S] exhibited homogeneous catalytic properties during the reaction, and the system can achieve spontaneous liquid–liquid partitioning after the reaction, which significantly simplifies the product separation process. The catalyst had the advantages of high catalytic efficiency, green renewability and easy operation, which provided a new catalytic system with the potential of industrialisation for biodiesel production.

coredata.dc:title: Novel proline p-toluenesulfonate ionic liquid as a recyclable catalyst for lauric acid esterification: process optimisation, kinetic and thermodynamic studies
